name: Freja Cellars Pinot Noir
notes: Bright red fruit core of cherry and raspberry, layered with subtle earth and baking spice. Silky texture, vibrant acidity, and a long finish with hints of rose petal and forest floor.
details: Freja Cellars is a small family-owned winery founded in 2005; this bottling comes from a single-vineyard block planted on volcanic soils, offering classic Oregon elegance and age-worthiness.

name: Domaine Berthoumieu Charles de Batz
notes: Opaque purple-ruby with a narrow garnet rim. The nose unfurls dense black fruits (blackberry, cassis, black cherry) woven with violet, licorice, cocoa, cedar and tobacco, plus a graphite/mineral edge. Full-bodied and powerful on the palate; the core is packed with ripe black fruits and dark chocolate, framed by abundant, fine-grained tannins typical of Tannat. Acidity is medium-high, bringing lift to the richness; oak is present but well-integrated, adding spice and toast without dominating. Savory undertones of dried herbs and a cool menthol/eucalyptus note emerge with air. The finish is long, vigorous and drying, with fruit, cocoa and cedar echoing for 30+ seconds. Decant 2–3 hours if drinking now; built for medium to long-term aging.
details: Flagship cuvée from Domaine Berthoumieu, named for Charles de Batz-Castelmore d'Artagnan—born nearby in Gascony. Typically 90% Tannat and 10% Cabernet Sauvignon from 50–100+ year-old vines; grapes are fully destemmed and fermented by variety (often in cement), with controlled micro-oxygenation—a technique pioneered in Madiran—to tame Tannat's formidable tannins. Élevage is about 12 months in French oak (≈50% new) before blending and light filtration. Madiran's clay-limestone and clay-siliceous soils, along with long, dry autumns, contribute to the wine's power, structure, and capacity to age.

name: Time Machine Blanc
notes: Pale straw with green highlights. The nose greets with bright citrus zest, Asian pear, fresh apple, and a flinty minerality. On the palate it is crisp and clean—medium-light-bodied with lively acidity, subtle floral hints, and a saline-tinged finish. Refreshing and elegant, echoing pear and lemon, with a gently chalky texture.
details: 2024 release by Bow & Arrow, loosely inspired by Loire Valley whites, blending mostly Chenin Blanc with splashes of Chardonnay and Melon de Bourgogne. Made in Portland, the winery embraces humble, drinkable terroir-driven natural wines. Organic farming, fermented in diverse vessels (steel, egg, old oak), light lees aging, low ABV and bright freshness characterize its style.

name: Bastide de la Ciselette Vin de Pays du Var Rosé
notes: Pale salmon with copper glints. Aromas open on wild raspberry, blood orange and ruby grapefruit layered with rosewater, white pepper and a faint sea-spray salinity. The palate is medium-light and brisk, showing vivid citrus and red berry fruit with a gently phenolic, lightly chalky texture from a short skin maceration; high natural acidity keeps it taut and refreshing. Savory notes of sage, rosemary and pink peppercorn add complexity. Dry, clean, and persistent, finishing long on citrus peel, mineral and pepper spice.
details: Founded in 2010, Bastide de la Ciselette became the 57th winery in the Bandol appellation; owner Robert DeSalvo and vigneron Romain Bournaud farm ~15 ha, incorporating organic and biodynamic methods. Vineyards lie on pebbly clay with abundant limestone in Bandol's south-facing amphitheater. This cuvée is labeled Vin de Pays du Var (regional indication rather than Bandol AOC). Typically 60% Grenache and 40% Merlot; hand-harvested fruit receives a brief skin maceration, is pressed pneumatically and fermented to dryness in tank, then held ~4 months before bottling to preserve freshness and natural acidity.

name: Murgo Etna Rosato
notes: Pale salmon/onion-skin hue with brilliant clarity. The nose opens on blood orange, white cherry and nectarine, layered with rose petals, lavender and a whisper of cinnamon, smoke and crushed volcanic rock. Medium-light on the palate with high, citrus-charged acidity and a faint phenolic snap from brief skin contact; flavors echo blood orange, wild strawberry and stone fruit over a saline, mineral spine. Texture is sleek and nervy yet mouthwatering; the finish is long, savory and stony with lingering citrus peel, pink pepper and sea-spray notes.
details: From vineyards on Mount Etna's eastern slopes around Zafferana Etnea (dark ash, mineral-rich volcanic soils; elevations up to ~1,000 m) where old, bush-trained alberelli vines are common. 100% Nerello Mascalese; grapes (30–40+ year vines) undergo a short cold maceration (~4 hours) before the free-run juice is drawn off for fermentation in tank. The wine rests about five months in tank and two months in bottle, emphasizing crisp acidity, mineral tension and a savory, smoky complexity characteristic of Etna rosatos.

name: Bodegas Ostatu Rioja Rosado
notes: Deep rosy pink/salmon hue. Expressive aromas of watermelon, ripe raspberry and cherry are laced with rose petal, fennel and a faint earthy spice. The palate is medium in body with a succulent, juicy core of red fruits; high-strung, mouthwatering acidity provides the signature snap and twang, while a subtle phenolic nibble from brief skin contact adds texture. Fermentation in stainless steel keeps it vivid and clean, finishing long on red citrus, mineral and light spice.
details: Intentional rosado from Certified Organic, high-elevation (600+ m) sites in Rioja Alavesa. Blend typically 63% Tempranillo, 35% Garnacha and 2% Viura; a short skin maceration is followed by a long, cool fermentation on native yeasts in stainless steel. The Sáenz de Samaniego family has farmed in Rioja Alavesa since the 16th century; wines under the Ostatu label began in 1970, and the estate was modernized in 2002 with input from Hubert de Boüard of Château Angélus.

name: Ernest Vineyards "Eugenia" Bruella Ranch Lodi Cinsault Rosé
notes: Dusty rose with a hint of onion-skin/orange at the rim. The nose leads with rosy florals and light spice over cranberry, red cherry and orange peel, joined by black tea, dried herbs and a faint mineral dust. Medium-light on the palate with bright, cutting acidity; flavors of tart red berries and citrus ride over a subtly savory, stony core and a gentle phenolic nip from brief skin contact. Stainless-steel precision keeps it crisp and clean. The finish is long and mouthwatering, echoing cranberry, tea and wet stone with a saline snap.
details: Produced under Ernest's "Eugenia" label devoted to rosé and exploratory projects. Sourced from Bruella Ranch east of Lodi, where Cinsault—naturally heat- and drought-tolerant—thrives in sandy-clay soils with some Pacific influence. After a brief skin maceration, the free-run juice ferments cool in stainless steel to preserve freshness and the variety's naturally high acidity. The 2022 release totaled approximately 675 cases, delivering a crisp, mineral, and food-flexible style.

name: Château Aney Haut-Médoc Cru Bourgeois
notes: Deep ruby with a garnet rim. Classic left-bank bouquet of cassis, blackberry and blackcurrant leaf layered with cedar, graphite, tobacco and pencil shavings. Medium-full on the palate with firm, fine Cabernet tannins, a gravelly mineral line and balanced, medium acidity; Merlot adds plummy flesh while Cab Franc/Petit Verdot bring spice and lift. Long, poised finish echoing cassis, cedar and graphite with a savory, dry close; elegant rather than massive, showing the vintage's ripeness with refined structure.
details: Estate in Cussac-Fort-Médoc between Saint-Julien and Margaux. Final blend mirrors plantings: ~65% Cabernet Sauvignon, 25% Merlot, 7% Cabernet Franc, 3% Petit Verdot. Fermented in a mix of concrete and stainless, aged ~1 year in barrels (≈30% new) and ~1 year in stainless pre-bottling. Built in 1850 by the Aney family; revived by the Raimond family after 1972, regaining Cru Bourgeois status.

name: Château de Landiras Graves Rouge
notes: Crimson-ruby core. Aromas of blackcurrant, black plum and blackberry framed by graphite, cedar, warm spice and a gentle cocoa/tobacco note. Medium body with supple Merlot mid-palate and Cabernet spine; tannins are polished yet persistent, acidity medium-plus for lift. Finishes savory and long on cassis, graphite and cacao with a faint gravelly mineral echo.
details: From the Left Bank's Graves AOC, known for sandy, gravelly clay over deep gravels. Blend ~65% Merlot, 35% Cabernet Sauvignon; fermented in temperature-controlled concrete tanks using only ambient yeasts. Aged ~12 months in French oak barriques (≈10% new). Historic château set in the heart of Graves; current ownership has introduced organic practices.

name: Château Lamoliere Fronsac
notes: Opaque ruby-purple. Plummy Merlot fruit and black cherry with damp violets, graphite, warm spice and a hint of green bell pepper from Cab Franc. Medium-full with a ripe, fleshy core, fine-grained tannins and lively, medium-plus acidity; oak is well-judged, adding subtle toast and sweetness. Long finish of dark plum, violets and spice over a limestone-chalky snap.
details: From rolling hills north of the Dordogne with abundant limestone and clay; vines average ~40 years. Blend ~86% Merlot and 14% Cabernet Franc. Fermented in tank, then transferred to used French oak barrels for ~12 months. Estate linked to Patrick Léon (ex-Mouton Rothschild/Almaviva/Opus One); part of Château Les Trois Croix.

name: Château La Vaisinerie Puisseguin Saint-Émilion
notes: Deep garnet-red. Aromas of red and black fruits—cranberry, cherry, damson plum and blackberry—woven with tobacco, dried herbs, licorice and crushed stone. Medium-full body with fine, grainy tannins and bright, medium-plus acidity; fruit purity balanced by savory earth and spice. Persistent finish that stays lifted and mineral alongside ripe Merlot flesh.
details: Small 17th-century estate (≈25 ha; 13 ha under vine) acquired in 2019 by négociant Alain Moses (Twins). Soils are classic clay/limestone; blend ~90% Merlot, 10% Cabernet Franc. Careful sorting and gentle vinification in concrete; ~50% aged 12–14 months in French barriques (≈1/3 new), remainder in tank. Puisseguin is among Saint-Émilion's stricter satellite AOCs.

name: Angelo Negro Langhe Nebbiolo "Angelin"
notes: Bright ruby-red. Perfumed nose of rose petal, violet and fresh red berries (raspberry, cherry) with orange peel and a faint anise/earth note. Medium body with a crunchy, youthful bite; tannins are present and chalky yet fine, acidity high and mouth-watering. Finishes long and lifted on red cherry, floral tones and mineral dust; nimble and energetic.
details: Sourced from holdings across Langhe and Roero; family grows grapes since the 1600s. Hand-picked Nebbiolo macerated in steel for ~15–18 days, then matured ~12 months in cask. Style emphasizes purity, florals and crunchy red fruit with firm, fine tannins.

name: Renzo Castella Langhe Nebbiolo
notes: Transparent ruby. Aromas of dark cherry and redcurrant with rose, violet, white pepper and subtle savory herbs over a stony undertone. Medium body with well-defined, firm tannins and a resonant line of high acidity; purity of cherry fruit carries through. Long, mineral finish with echoes of rose and pepper; structure reminiscent of Barolo in a more approachable frame.
details: Fruit from a herbicide- and pesticide-free vineyard near the Diano d'Alba/Serralunga border (Barolo area limestone influence). Destemmed, fermented in large neutral oak 'tini' ~1 week on skins; racked to stainless for malolactic and ~8 months' aging. Family farm founded in the early 1900s; Renzo transitioned to estate bottling.

name: De Forville Nebbiolo d'Alba "San Rocco"
notes: Ruby-garnet. Somber dark-fruit profile—black cherry, plum and blackberry—lifted by rose, violet and subtle balsamic/tea notes. Medium body with firm, pithy tannins shaped by an extended skin fermentation; acidity bright and refreshing. Persistent, savory finish with mineral drive and refined grip; approachable yet serious.
details: From San Rocco d'Elvio near Alba. Hand-harvested; fermented on skins in stainless up to four weeks to tame/shape tannins; then racked to large 50-hl oak barrels for ~1 year before bottling. De Forville-Anfosso family farms ~11 ha across Barbaresco/Neive with a 150-year history.

name: Tiziano Mazzoni Colline Novaresi Nebbiolo "del Monteregio"
notes: Luminous garnet-red with pink/orange reflections. Perfumed nose of bing cherry, crushed red raspberry and rose petal over citrus peel, leather, subtle spice and mineral. Medium body with fine-grained, gently assertive tannins and fresh, high acidity; sleek and precise. Smooth, savory finish that lingers on red fruit, rose and a hint of pepper and leather.
details: From Cavaglio d'Agogna in the hills east of Ghemme (Alto Piemonte). Hand-harvested, destemmed; fermented with indigenous yeasts in stainless with ~10-day maceration; aged ~1 year in used 500-L French oak tonneaux. Bottled unfined and unfiltered; farming follows organic principles.

name: Copper Six Alisos Canyon Gamay
notes: Vibrant ruby with violet flashes. Aromas leap from the glass—mountain raspberry, rosehip and black cherry—over crushed granite, chai spice and a twist of white pepper. The palate is lively and medium-bodied with bright, mouth-watering acidity; juicy red fruits are framed by fine, chalk-edged tannins from a touch of whole-cluster. Finishes long, stony and perfumed with violets and herbs; delicious slightly chilled.
details: Hand-harvested in two passes (late September/early October). After sorting and destemming into open-top tanks, ~25% whole clusters were included; gentle daily pump-overs. A portion barrel-fermented; aging in a mix of neutral French oak (225L, 300L, 500L) prior to bottling to preserve the AVA's cool-Pacific, sandstone/shale-driven freshness.

name: Leah Jorgensen Gamay Le Coeur de Tour Rain – Havlin Vineyard
notes: Clear ruby. Lively scents of wild red cherry, raspberry and cranberry with violets, peppercorn and a hint of baking spice. Medium in body with bright, driving acidity; tangy red fruit flows across a silken mid-palate, framed by fine, powdery tannins. Long, pepper-tinged finish that remains energetic and food-versatile.
details: Hand-harvested and selectively sorted from Havlin Vineyard (ancient marine-influenced soils of shellfish, limestone and clay loam). Spontaneous fermentation on skins in stainless; then aged in neutral French oak to showcase terroir. No additives or shortcuts—an authentic, terroir-driven Gamay.

name: Domaine du Gueret Moulin-à-Vent
notes: Deep ruby. Intense blackcurrant and black cherry layered with violet, licorice, woody nuance and a ferrous, granitic mineral tone. The palate is ripe and full-bodied for Gamay, with firm, finely knit tannins and brisk acidity giving length and poise. Long, savory finish etched by spice and granite dust—delicious now, with clear potential to develop complexity over a few years.
details: Estate parcels around La Bruyère on manganese- and iron-rich granite slopes. Hand harvest; rigorous sorting; long macerations with whole-bunch fermentations (~10–15 days). Partial élevage in large, neutral oak to add depth without overt wood. The Favre-Curtelin family stewards ~13 ha split between Chénas and MAV; cellar dates to the 18th century.

name: Domaine des Gryphées Balmes Vieilles Vignes
notes: Deep, reflective ruby with purple highlights. Soaring aromatics of black cherry, ripe strawberry and wild raspberry over spiced plum, blueberry, candied violet, grape stem, crushed stones and a touch of pepper and forest floor. Medium-bodied and supple with polished tannins and bright, refreshing acidity; fruit generosity is balanced by a savory mineral line. Long, mouth-watering finish that invites another sip.
details: From the steep 'Balmes' vineyard in Le Bois d'Oingt (Pierres Dorées zone), on limestone- and clay-rich soils with golden chalk. Ancient 90–100-year-old, low-yielding vines harvested by hand. Indigenous-yeast fermentation in stainless; pressed to old, neutral foudres for élevage; bottled with minimal intervention to preserve purity and site character. Estate managed by Pierre and Guillaume Durdilly.
